natural problem: I have 6 shirts, 4 pairs of pants, and 6 hats. The pants come in tan, black, blue, and gray. The shirts and hats come in those colors, and also white and yellow. I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color. How many choices for outfits, consisting of one shirt, one hat, and one pair of pants, do I have?
natural solution: The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 4\times 6=144$. There are 4 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
Thus there are $144-4=\boxed{140}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes shirts pants hats outfits :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 4"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "\<forall>shirt_color pant_color hat_color. shirt_color = pant_color \<and> pant_color = hat_color \<longrightarrow> outfits \<noteq> 1"
shows  "outfits = 140"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 6 shirts, 4 pairs of pants, and 6 hats. The pants come in tan, black, blue, and gray. The shirts and hats come in those colors, and also white and yellow. I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color. How many choices for outfits, consisting of one shirt, one hat, and one pair of pants, do I have? The final Answer is 140
 ### Proof
 The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 4\times 6=144$. There are 4 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
 Thus there are $144-4=\boxed{140}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
 *)

theorem
fixes shirts pants hats outfits :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 4"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "\<forall>shirt_color pant_color hat_color. shirt_color = pant_color \<and> pant_color = hat_color \<longrightarrow> outfits \<noteq> 1"
shows  "outfits = 140"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: There are 6 shirts, 4 pants, and 6 hats in a store. You want to buy one of each, but you cannot choose the same color for all three items. How many different outfits can you create? The final answer is 140.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 4"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "shirts * pants * hats - (shirts - 2) * (pants - 2) * (hats - 2) = 140"
shows  "shirts * pants * hats - (shirts - 2) * (pants - 2) * (hats - 2) = 140"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 6 shirts, 4 pairs of pants, and 6 hats. The pants come in tan, black, blue, and gray. The shirts and hats come in those colors, and also white and yellow. I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color. How many choices for outfits, consisting of one shirt, one hat, and one pair of pants, do I have? The final Answer is 140
 ### Proof
 The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 4\times 6=144$. There are 4 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
 Thus there are $144-4=\boxed{140}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
 *)

theorem
fixes shirts pants hats :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 4"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "shirts * pants * hats - (shirts - 2) * (pants - 2) * (hats - 2) = 140"
shows  "shirts * pants * hats - (shirts - 2) * (pants - 2) * (hats - 2) = 140"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 6 shirts, 4 pants, and 6 hats. Find the difference between the total number of combinations of shirts, pants, and hats and the total number of combinations after removing 2 shirts, 2 pants, and 2 hats. The final answer is 140.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes shirts pants hats outfits :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 4"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "outfits = shirts * pants * hats - pants"
shows  "outfits = 140"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 6 shirts, 4 pairs of pants, and 6 hats. The pants come in tan, black, blue, and gray. The shirts and hats come in those colors, and also white and yellow. I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color. How many choices for outfits, consisting of one shirt, one hat, and one pair of pants, do I have? The final Answer is 140
 ### Proof
 The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 4\times 6=144$. There are 4 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
 Thus there are $144-4=\boxed{140}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
 *)

theorem
fixes shirts pants hats outfits :: nat
assumes h0 : "shirts = 6"
and h1 : "pants = 4"
and h2 : "hats = 6"
and h3 : "outfits = shirts * pants * hats - pants"
shows  "outfits = 140"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There are 6 shirts, 4 pants, and 6 hats. How many different outfits can be made by choosing one shirt, one pant, and one hat, if 4 pants are subtracted from the total combinations? The final answer is 140 outfits.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_outfits :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_outfits = (6 * 4 * 6)"
and h1 : "4 = CARD {Tan, Black, Blue, Gray}"
and h2 : "6 = CARD {Tan, Black, Blue, Gray, White, Yellow}"
and h3 : "total_outfits - 4 = 140"
shows  "total_outfits = 144"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 6 shirts, 4 pairs of pants, and 6 hats. The pants come in tan, black, blue, and gray. The shirts and hats come in those colors, and also white and yellow. I refuse to wear an outfit in which all 3 items are the same color. How many choices for outfits, consisting of one shirt, one hat, and one pair of pants, do I have? The final Answer is 140
 ### Proof
 The number of all outfit combinations is $6\times 4\times 6=144$. There are 4 outfits in which all three items are the same color.
 Thus there are $144-4=\boxed{140}$ outfits in which not all three items are the same color.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_outfits :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_outfits = (6 * 4 * 6)"
and h1 : "4 = CARD {Tan, Black, Blue, Gray}"
and h2 : "6 = CARD {Tan, Black, Blue, Gray, White, Yellow}"
and h3 : "total_outfits - 4 = 140"
shows  "total_outfits = 144"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A person has 6 shirts, 4 pants, and 6 pairs of socks in different colors. The pants colors are {Tan, Black, Blue, Gray}, and the socks colors are {Tan, Black, Blue, Gray, White, Yellow}. How many different outfits can be made using one shirt, one pair of pants, and one pair of socks? The final answer is 144.
